Misc

I'd heard from a few astrophotographers that wanted an app to track space objects. They all had the same complaints about their current technology - it was too complicated, slow, and bloated. With that in mind I set out to make a simple app to track the International Space Station.

The Data

Finding the right source for the right data was the first task. There's a number of APIs that have information on the Space Station, including NASA itself, and the best choice had a few criteria to meet.

  • Open Source - the API had to meet FSM criteria. All code should be freely available..
  • Accurate - at any given moment the APIs predictions and the NASA stated position should be the same.
  • Easily accessible - keys and accounts are ok, but no paywalls or anything impeding access.

Accuracy

Checking the chosen API prediction times against the current NASA location returned good results. Any incorrect predictions were outliers and those outliers were within an acceptable 10-minute margin of error.

With that finished I had to decide on the development stack:

  • GraphQL - the API feeds us a huge amount of data we don't need, which makes it a good candidate for GraphQL.
  • React - reusable components and fast iteration: the perfect option.
